required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Functionality and Accuracy of the smARTrack System in Real-Life ICU Settings
clinical_study.official_title: Functionality and Accuracy of the smARTrack System in Real-Life ICU Settings

brief_summary.textblock: This study conducted in order to validate the functionality and accuracy of the smARTrack™ System in a real-life ICU setting. The smARTrack™ Feeding Tube System is a novel system with nasogastric tube developed by ART Healthcare Ltd, based on sensor-lined tubes that transmit real-time information to an external console. The smARTrack™ feeding tube is equipped with reflux sensors which alert when gastric contents regurgitating into the esophagus. In addition, the smARTrack™ feeding tube is equipped with sensors designed to provide information about the location of the tube thus assisting in reducing the incident of misplacement during first positioning. The smARTrack™ feeding tube is also automatically and in real-time stops feeding if the feeding tube moves out of position during ongoing use or detect gastric content in esophagus. Furthermore, smARTrack™ Feeding Tube System can guide operator to correctly re-position the tube.

primary_outcome.measure: System accurately guides correct initial placement
primary_outcome.description: The system is able to accurately guide the user to ensure correct initial placement (verified by X-ray)

primary_outcome.measure: System accurately detects tube movement/displacement during ongoing use
primary_outcome.description: The system is able to detect tube movement/displacement during ongoing use (verified by markings on the tube)

primary_outcome.measure: System automatically stops feeding when displacement is detected
primary_outcome.description: The system automatically stops feeding when tube displacement is detected

primary_outcome.measure: System is able to detect overfeeding
primary_outcome.description: The system is able to detect overfeeding

primary_outcome.measure: Occurrence of device related Adverse Events (Safety)
primary_outcome.description: Occurrence of device related adverse events

secondary_outcome.measure: The system user interface is easy for use
secondary_outcome.description: Ease of use of the system and the user interface by subjective questionnaire of staff

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of impedance detected to patient positioning
secondary_outcome.description: Recording of impedance detected by the system and correlation to patient positioning

secondary_outcome.measure: Quantification of the amount of discarded nutritional supplement by implementing GRV test
secondary_outcome.description: Quantification of the amount of discarded nutritional supplement by implementing GRV test as needed and according to hospital procedures

secondary_outcome.measure: Aspiration of gastric contents percentage compared to standard feeding (as reported in literature)
secondary_outcome.description: Reduction of aspiration of gastric contents percentage compared to standard feeding (as reported in literature).

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation between patient clinical information and the occurrence of reflux and sensors data
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation between patient clinical information and the occurrence of reflux and sensors data.

arm_group.description: One arm study: smARTrack Feeding Tube System.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Males and females 18 years or older
- Patient has already been admitted to ICU
- Patient requires enteral feeding
- Patients receiving PPI therapy
- Informed consent by independent physician and next of kin
- ICU ventilated patients
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with anomalies or diseases of the nose, throat, or esophagus and or stomach.
- Patients with known sensitivities or allergies to any of the feeding tube materials
- Inability to place patient is semi-Fowler's position.
- Any clinically significant abnormality upon physical examination which may, in the opinion of the investigator, pose difficulty in inserting the feeding tube (e.g. cervical spine disorder)
- Pregnancy
- Recent abdominal surgery (less than 30 days)
